title: ORD | Lausanne
description: The Lausanne meeting will take place at EPFL in the morning and University of Lausanne during the afternoon. The nearest metro stop for the morning is UNIL Sorge and for the afternoon is UNIL Chamberonne. The morning sessions will take place in the CM 1 4 Auditorium, and the afternoon sessions will be in different rooms (3059, 3148, 5135, 5146) of the Anthropole building.

timeline.title: Performing research with publicly-available data
timeline.description: The importance of Open Research Data has gained significant recognition within the scientific community, fostering transparency, collaboration, and innovation. This presentation introduces participants to the world of Open Research Data, inspiring them to adopt good practices that can benefit their research endeavors across various disciplines, including chemistry, materials science, and linguistics.  Moreover, I will be showcasing a few examples where open data had an impact and unlocked exciting science.

timeline.title: Data interoperability
timeline.description:
Despite an ever-growing number of data sets that catalog and characterize interactions between microbes in different environments and conditions, many of these data are neither easily accessible nor intercompatible. These limitations present a major challenge to microbiome research by hindering the streamlined drawing of inferences across studies. Here, we propose guiding principles to make microbial data more findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable (FAIR).
We outline specific use cases for interaction and sequence data that span the diverse space of microbiome research, and discuss the untapped potential for new insights that can be fulfilled through broader integration of microbial interaction data. These include, among others, the design of intercompatible synthetic communities for environmental, industrial, or medical applications, and the inference of novel interactions from disparate studies. Lastly, we describe work in progress for the deployment of FAIR microbial data based on existing resources, reporting standards, and current momentum within the community.

speaker.name: Alan Pacheco
speaker.long_description: Alan Pacheco is a James S. McDonnell postdoctoral fellow in the Vorholt group at ETH Zurich. He received his Ph.D. in 2021 from Boston University, where he studied how the behavior of microbial ecosystems could be modulated by tuning specific environmental features. His current research applies these principles to the microbiomes of plant leaves through the use of computational modeling, while also developing methods to catalogue and analyze the diversity of microbial interactions more generally.

speaker.name: Lina Kim
speaker.long_description: Lina Kim is a doctoral candidate at the ETH Zürich Laboratory for Food Systems Biotechnology. Through experiences as an academic researcher at MIT and bioinformatician in the biotechnology industry, she developed an appreciation for multi-omics technologies and their relevance to human health. Her current research involves developing and applying computational methods to complex microbial communities in stem cell patient outcomes.

workshops.title: Introduction to Git, GitHub, GitLab
workshops.description:
The course is structured into an introductory presentation and a hands-on session to get familiar with using git. We will start with basic principles and git commands.
As a prerequisite, you can have a look at the `hands on bash` tutorial.

speaker.name: Romain Graux
speaker.description: Data Officer at NCCR Catalysis, EPFL

workshops.title: Managing and Anonymizing Sensitive Data
workshops.description:
In the era of Open Science, researchers are increasingly required to share their research data. Not only do funders expect the sharing of data after the project’s completion, but also an increasing number of scientific journals make data sharing a condition for publication. While researchers tend to express positive attitudes towards data sharing, this is not without posing several legal, ethical and practical challenges. This holds particularly for researchers working with sensitive data, as they are subject to strict rules and principles. In the first part, this workshop will provide theoretical and practical insights for sharing sensitive data and meet Open Science requirements.
The second part of the workshop will deal with the topic of anonymisation of quantitative research data. It will present key concepts of anonymisation to help researchers to develop an appropriate anonymization strategy, and to provide the main techniques for anonymizing their data. Examples will be discussed along small exercises. The workshop takes a social sciences perspective but is relevant to anyone working with sensitive data. It will alternate between presentations and short exercises, which will allow to understand the challenges related to this topic in a practical way.

speaker.name: Marieke Heers
speaker.long_description: Marieke Heers is a senior researcher at the Swiss Centre of Expertise in the Social Sciences (FORS), where she works in the group Data Management Support. Marieke is an expert on data management with respect to social sciences data. She holds a PhD in the economics of education and is involved in research projects on education and migration.

workshops.title: Uploading data to repositories
workshops.description:
Uploading your research data to a public repository is critical to openness. It is a required practice by the Swiss NSF because it allows other researchers to find and reproduce publicly funded work.
In this workshop, participants will learn how to upload their data efficiently and responsibly, so that their work aligns with the FAIR principles of findability, accessibility, interoperability, and reproducibility. By the end of the session, participants will be able to:
  • Identify the right repository for a given data set.
  • Streamline the process of uploading data.
  • Annotate data in a standard way, so that other researchers can understand them.
  • Understand the value of publishing protocols.

speaker.name: Kendra Brown
speaker.long_description: Kendra Brown is the data manager of the NCCR Microbiomes. She has a PhD in Environmental Engineering from Stanford University, and worked as an environmental consultant before joining the NCCR. She is dedicated to helping NCCR members adopt Open Research Data practices, because to solve the world’s challenges we need to make the best possible use of scientific data.

workshops.title: Codebooks for survey and interview data as part of a data management infrastructure
workshops.description:
Infrastructures are things you notice once they break down. You don’t think much about the sewers or wi-fi networks until you dearly miss them. If you want Open Research Data to work, you will need some corresponding infrastructure.
In this talk we will address a modest looking document, the codebook, and pull a few loose strings that end up connected to the semantic web, international standards, associations of librarians and swiss graphic design. We will look at a free tool that is both obsolete and a door to interconnected research data, the Nesstar Publisher.
In addition, we will discuss a specific research project as a case study that combines different data collection strategies to examine the challenges associated with developing common codebooks across data types that differ in terms of anonymization and thickness of topics covered.

speaker.name: Andreas Perret
speaker.long_description: Andreas Perret is the Data Manager of the nccr – on the move, where he coordinates all matters linked to data management plans, data visualization and open access policy. He has previously led the medical hospital statistics at the Swiss Federal Statistical Office before heading the dissemination of public statistics at the social data archive FORS. He holds a master’s degree in sociology and anthropology, was an expert in conflict management and started his career as a professional photographer.

speaker.name: Eva Fernandez
speaker.long_description: Eva Fernández Guzmán G. is a scientific collaborator at the University of Geneva and a post-doctoral fellow at the University of Trento. She holds a PhD in Political Science and Sociology and her research focuses on immigration, solidarity and political behavior. She has also worked in the public health sector, mainly at the World Health Organization where she was part of the monitoring and evaluation team.

keypoints: Feel free to hijack the tools that do the job, bricolage is king
Trust your Data Librarian, she stands on much thicker shoulders than your IT specialist
It ain’t good if it don’t look good
Mixed-methods based strategies allow for generalization and thickness to be built into our data collection
Combining data types involves connecting the dots early in the project, developing guidelines toward a common target and codebooks that can be read across data sets
